Re ''South Africa in Quandary: Should Gays Donate Blood?'' (news article, June 11):

A few years ago I was walking by a blood drive. A volunteer asked me if I would be willing to donate blood. I told her that the Red Cross won't take my blood, even though I am free of disease and a universal donor.
When she asked me why, I replied, ''Because I'm gay.'' Her face went white, her eyes distant, and she asked, ''Why couldn't my husband have been that up front with me?''
The Red Cross's policy is based on the same bigotry that kept that woman's husband so deeply closeted that perhaps even he didn't know he was gay when they married.

I am a perfectly healthy man. I am not promiscuous and don't engage in unsafe sex. The next time you hear about an acute need for type O blood, ask yourself why the American Red Cross won't take mine.
